user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_bd_read:
```c
static int lfs_bd_read(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_cache_t *pcache, lfs_cache_t *rcache, lfs_size_t hint,
        lfs_block_t block, lfs_off_t off,
        void *buffer, lfs_size_t size) {
    uint8_t *data = buffer;
    if (off+size > lfs->cfg->block_size
            || (lfs->block_count && block >= lfs->block_count)) {
        return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
    }

    while (size > 0) {
        lfs_size_t diff = size;

        if (pcache && block == pcache->block &&
                off < pcache->off + pcache->size) {
            if (off >= pcache->off) {
                // is already in pcache?
                diff = lfs_min(diff, pcache->size - (off-pcache->off));
                memcpy(data, &pcache->buffer[off-pcache->off], diff);

                data += diff;
                off += diff;
                size -= diff;
                continue;
            }

            // pcache takes priority
            diff = lfs_min(diff, pcache->off-off);
        }

        if (block == rcache->block &&
                off < rcache->off + rcache->size) {
            if (off >= rcache->off) {
                // is already in rcache?
                diff = lfs_min(diff, rcache->size - (off-rcache->off));
                memcpy(data, &rcache->buffer[off-rcache->off], diff);

                data += diff;
                off += diff;
                size -= diff;
                continue;
            }

            // rcache takes priority
            diff = lfs_min(diff, rcache->off-off);
        }

        if (size >= hint && off % lfs->cfg->read_size == 0 &&
                size >= lfs->cfg->read_size) {
            // bypass cache?
            diff = lfs_aligndown(diff, lfs->cfg->read_size);
            int err = lfs->cfg->read(lfs->cfg, block, off, data, diff);
            if (err) {
                return err;
            }

            data += diff;
            off += diff;
            size -= diff;
            continue;
        }

        // load to cache, first condition can no longer fail
        LFS_ASSERT(!lfs->block_count || block < lfs->block_count);
        rcache->block = block;
        rcache->off = lfs_aligndown(off, lfs->cfg->read_size);
        rcache->size = lfs_min(
                lfs_min(
                    lfs_alignup(off+hint, lfs->cfg->read_size),
                    lfs->cfg->block_size)
                - rcache->off,
                lfs->cfg->cache_size);
        int err = lfs->cfg->read(lfs->cfg, rcache->block,
                rcache->off, rcache->buffer, rcache->size);
        LFS_ASSERT(err <= 0);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return 0;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function lfs_bd_read:
typedef uint32_t lfs_size_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_block_t
...
typedef uint32_t lfs_off_t
...
typedef struct lfs_cache {
    lfs_block_t block;
    lfs_off_t off;
    lfs_size_t size;
    uint8_t *buffer;
} lfs_cache_t
...
typedef struct lfs {
    lfs_cache_t rcache;
    lfs_cache_t pcache;

    lfs_block_t root[2];
    struct lfs_mlist {
        struct lfs_mlist *next;
        uint16_t id;
        uint8_t type;
        lfs_mdir_t m;
    } *mlist;
    uint32_t seed;

    lfs_gstate_t gstate;
    lfs_gstate_t gdisk;
    lfs_gstate_t gdelta;

    struct lfs_lookahead {
        lfs_block_t start;
        lfs_block_t size;
        lfs_block_t next;
        lfs_block_t ckpoint;
        uint8_t *buffer;
    } lookahead;

    const struct lfs_config *cfg;
    lfs_size_t block_count;
    lfs_size_t name_max;
    lfs_size_t file_max;
    lfs_size_t attr_max;
    lfs_size_t inline_max;

#ifdef LFS_MIGRATE
    struct lfs1 *lfs1;
#endif
} lfs_t
...
#define LFS_ASSERT(test) assert(test)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no controlling expressions that appear to be invariant and therefore requiring investigation for MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. Reasoning for the main controlling expressions:

- while (size > 0): 'size' is modified on each progress path (size -= diff) before the next loop iteration, so the loop control is not invariant. The code also contains explicit continue paths that advance 'off'/'data'/'size', and the cache-load path populates rcache so a subsequent iteration will copy and reduce 'size'.

- if (pcache && block == pcache->block && off < pcache->off + pcache->size) and nested if (off >= pcache->off): these tests depend on function inputs and on 'off' which is adjusted within the loop; their truth value can change across iterations (pcache may be NULL or non-NULL but that is an input-dependent runtime condition, not a compile-time invariant). They are not compile-time invariant controlling expressions.

- if (block == rcache->block && off < rcache->off + rcache->size) and nested checks: rcache fields are updated inside the function (rcache->block, rcache->off, rcache->size), and 'off' is updated, so these conditions are not invariant across iterations.

- if (size >= hint && off % lfs->cfg->read_size == 0 && size >= lfs->cfg->read_size): this depends on 'size' and 'off' which change during the loop; not invariant.

- There are no for-loops or do-while loops in this function. The only loop is the while above and it is not invariant as explained.

- Assertions (LFS_ASSERT(...)) and calls to cfg->read are not loop-controlling expressions subject to Rule 14.3 in this context.

Given the above, there are no code fragments in this function that present an invariant controlling expression that would violate Rule 14.3 and thus no fragments to report for further investigation.
